title: Comprehensive Introduction to Calculus: Limits and Derivatives

content_data.1: Understand the concept of a limit and its significance in calculus.
content_data.2: Learn how to calculate limits using various methods.
content_data.3: Define the derivative and understand its geometric interpretation.
content_data.4: Apply the rules of differentiation to find derivatives of functions.

Limits.definition: A limit is the value that a function approaches as the input approaches a certain point.
Limits.notation: lim (x → a) f(x) = L means as x approaches a, f(x) approaches L.
Limits.one_sided_limits: Limits can be approached from the left (denoted as lim (x → a-) f(x)) or from the right (denoted as lim (x → a+) f(x)).

Derivatives.definition: The derivative of a function at a point measures the rate at which the function value changes as its input changes.
Derivatives.notation: f'(x) or dy/dx represents the derivative of f with respect to x.
Derivatives.geometric_interpretation: The derivative represents the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a given point.
examples: If f(x) = sin(x), then f'(x) = cos(x).

Derivative Examples.2: Find the derivative of f(x) = ln(x).

content_data.Limits: Limits are foundational in calculus, allowing us to understand behavior of functions at specific points.
content_data.Derivatives: Derivatives provide insight into the rate of change of functions, essential for graphing and optimization.
